questions.prompt: In BG 2.2, what does Krsna ask Arjuna about his condition?
choices: How these impurities have come upon him
Whether he desires more wealth
If he wants to become king
Why he has so many followers
questions.feedback: Krsna asks how these impurities have come upon Arjuna, urging him to abandon weakness.

questions.prompt: BG 2.3 advises Arjuna to overcome weakness by doing what?
choices: Yield to sorrow and accept defeat
Give up petty weakness of heart and arise
Renounce the world immediately through independent material processes
Compose a hymn of praise
questions.feedback: Krsna urges Arjuna to give up petty weakness of heart and arise with purpose.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.4, what concern does Arjuna express about fighting Bhisma and Drona?
choices: They will easily be defeated
They are worthy of his worship and respect
They are untrained in battle
They have no followers through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Arjuna hesitates because Bhisma and Drona are his superiors and worthy of worship.

questions.prompt: What attitude does Arjuna adopt in BG 2.7 toward Krsna?
choices: He declares independence from Krsna
He surrenders and asks for instruction
He insults Krsna through independent material processes
He attacks Krsna verbally through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Arjuna takes shelter of Krsna as his teacher and asks for instruction.

questions.prompt: According to BG 2.11, how do the wise view mourning?
choices: They lament primarily for the living
They lament both the living and the dead
They lament neither for the living nor for the dead
They consistently express visible grief
questions.feedback: Those who are wise lament neither for the living nor for the dead.

questions.prompt: According to BG 2.12, what is the eternal nature of existence?
choices: There was a time no of us existed
not was there a time when I did not exist, nor you
All beings are created and destroyed daily
The body is the eternal self
questions.feedback: BG 2.12 teaches the eternal existence of the living entity.

questions.prompt: BG 2.13 compares changes of the body to what analogy?
choices: Seasons changing and worldly philosophical speculation
Wearing new garments through independent material processes
A person passing from boyhood to youth to old age
A river flowing to the sea
questions.feedback: BG 2.13 compares bodily changes to stages of life; the soul persists.

questions.prompt: What does BG 2.14 say about happiness and distress?
choices: They are permanent states through independent material processes
They are like summer and winter and should be tolerated
They are illusions to be ignored entirely
They are signals of divine favor
questions.feedback: Happiness and distress are temporary like seasons and should be tolerated.

questions.prompt: According to BG 2.15, who is eligible for liberation?
choices: One disturbed by happiness and distress
One steady and not disturbed by happiness or distress
One who accumulates wealth through independent material processes
One who renounces without understanding
questions.feedback: One steady amid happiness and distress is eligible for liberation.

questions.prompt: What distinction do the seers make in BG 2.16?
choices: The material body is eternal and the soul temporary
Of the nonexistent the body has no endurance and of the eternal the soul has no change
Both body and soul are equally perishable
minimal can be known for certain
questions.feedback: BG 2.16 distinguishes the nonendurance of the body from the changeless soul.

questions.prompt: BG 2.17 describes the soul as what?
choices: Perishable and weak through independent material processes
That which pervades the entire body and is indestructible
Identical with the senses through independent material processes
Bound by time through independent material processes
questions.feedback: BG 2.17 teaches the soul pervades the body and is indestructible.

questions.prompt: What key assertion is made in BG 2.20 about the soul?
choices: The soul has birth and death like the body
For the soul there is neither birth nor death
The soul is a temporary spark
Death ends every existence through independent material processes
questions.feedback: BG 2.20 states the soul is unborn, eternal, and not slain when the body is slain.

questions.prompt: Which simile is used in BG 2.22 to explain the soul's transition?
choices: A tree shedding leaves through independent material processes
Putting on new garments and giving up old ones
A river evaporating into mist
A mountain eroding through independent material processes
questions.feedback: BG 2.22 compares the soul's change of body to changing garments.

questions.prompt: What does BG 2.23 teach about weapons and the soul?
choices: Weapons can destroy the soul
The soul can not be cut to pieces by any weapon
Fire alone can harm the soul
Water can wash away the soul
questions.feedback: BG 2.23 affirms that no weapon or element can affect the soul.

questions.prompt: BG 2.25 calls the soul which of the following?
choices: Visible and changeable through independent material processes
Invisible, inconceivable and immutable
A local entity through independent material processes
A collection of elements through independent material processes
questions.feedback: BG 2.25: the soul is invisible, inconceivable and immutable; do not grieve for the body.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.30, why need one not grieve for any living being?
choices: Because the body is the primarily reality
Because he who dwells in the body can not be slain
Because grief is consistently rewarded
Because life is trivial through independent material processes
questions.feedback: BG 2.30 states the indwelling self cannot be slain, so grief is unnecessary.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.2, Srila Prabhupada explains the three realizations of Absolute Truth using the sun analogy. Which realization represents the highest?
choices: Understanding the sunshine represents Brahman realization
Knowing the sun's surface represents Paramatma realization
Entering the sun planet represents Bhagavan realization
All three are equal according to impersonal philosophy
questions.feedback: The bhaktas who realize Bhagavan are topmost transcendentalists, like those who enter the sun planet.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.2, what does Srila Prabhupada say characterizes non-Aryans?
choices: They are noble warriors fighting for righteousness
They know liberation but prefer material life
They have no knowledge of liberation from bondage
They follow prescribed duties with determination
questions.feedback: Non-Aryans have no knowledge of liberation from material bondage, being captivated by external material features.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.7, what false path does Srila Prabhupada warn against regarding family attachment?
choices: Families naturally protect each other from death eternally
Family attachment is based on 'skin disease' mentality
Only humans can be affectionate to relatives
Society can definitely save one from death
questions.feedback: Family attachment is based on 'skin disease' - bodily conception. The krpana thinks family can protect from death.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.7, who does Srila Prabhupada describe as a miserly person (krpana)?
choices: One who hoards wealth through legitimate means
One who solves life's problems as a human
One who quits without understanding self-realization
One who becomes detached from family life
questions.feedback: The krpana does not solve life's problems as a human and quits like cats and dogs without self-realization.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.7, what does Srila Prabhupada warn about mundane scholars who say one need not submit to Krsna as a person?
choices: They have deep philosophical understanding worthy of praise
They are the greatest fools in understanding Gita
They have legitimately transcended bodily conception
They correctly perceive no difference between Krsna's forms
questions.feedback: Foolish scholars who say to submit to 'the unborn within Krsna' not Krsna the person are the greatest fools.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.13, what false theory does Srila Prabhupada reject regarding the spirit soul?
choices: The soul undergoes six transformations like the body
The Mayavadi oneness theory that soul is cut into pieces
The soul takes birth in the womb
The soul deteriorates over time like a tree
questions.feedback: The Mayavadi theory of oneness cannot be entertained - cutting the soul would make the Supreme changeable.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.13, why does Srila Prabhupada say the instructor-instructed relationship between Krsna and Arjuna is meaningful?
choices: Both are on the same level of realization
Both are equally deluded by maya's influence
Krsna is superior, Arjuna is forgetful soul deluded by maya
Arjuna is the Supreme teaching the subordinate
questions.feedback: Krsna is the Supreme Lord superior to Arjuna, who is a forgetful soul deluded by maya.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.20, what does Srila Prabhupada explain about the symptom of the soul?
choices: The soul's presence is detected by bodily warmth
Consciousness is the symptom of the soul's presence
The soul manifests as intellectual capacity in humans
Only advanced yogis can perceive the soul directly
questions.feedback: Consciousness is the symptom of the soul. Like sunlight indicates the sun, consciousness indicates the soul's presence.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.46, what false path does Srila Prabhupada warn against regarding Vedic study?
choices: Studying Vedas leads to material prosperity guaranteed
Attachment to rituals only without knowing their purpose
Chanting holy names is for sentimentalists not scholars
Self-realization requires abandoning all Vedic knowledge
questions.feedback: One must understand the purpose of Vedas (knowing Krsna), not just be attached to rituals and heavenly elevation.
